feed.title: Wikimedia Design Strategy
feed.subtitle: Design and user research projects at Wikimedia Foundation.

entry.title: User Engagement with the Wikipedia App Explore Feed
entry.summary: A mixed-method study examining perceptions of the Wikipedia Explore Feed and opportunities to improve engagement.
entry.content:
Initiative: Sentiment & Perception

A mixed-method study examining perceptions of the Wikipedia Explore Feed and opportunities to improve engagement.

entry.title: Mapping non-emergency support structures
entry.summary: Documenting local help and support structures, especially for conflict resolution, across four wikis to inform recommendations for the Incident Reporting System.
entry.content:
Initiative: Online Social Behavior

entry.title: Volunteer Archetypes V2
entry.summary: While V1 Archetypes research engaged with both off-Wiki volunteer contributors and previous research conducted by the WMF, V2 intends to provide a strong empirical basis for Archetypes by expanding the size and number of populations engaged.
entry.content:
Initiative: Numeric Exploration

While V1 Archetypes research engaged with both off-Wiki volunteer contributors and previous research conducted by the WMF, V2 intends to provide a strong empirical basis for Archetypes by expanding the size and number of populations engaged.

entry.title: MinT (Machine in Translation) Research
entry.summary: The goal of this project was to understand how to better leverage MinT to support more readers and contributors in their aims of accessing, interacting with, and contributing to Wikipedia content, as well as knowledge more generally.

Lead: Eli Asikin-Garmager and Claudia Lo

author.name: Eli Asikin-Garmager and Claudia Lo

entry.title: Momentum: Contribution, Content, & Reading in Wiki Growth
entry.summary: This study test some key hypotheses: that building awareness of the brand drives more people to read our content; that by growing readership the Movement itself grows as readers are converted into content contributors; that as the community grows so does the amount and diversity of content offered; and that more, and more diverse, content attracts more readers.
entry.content:
Initiative: Numeric Exploration

This study test some key hypotheses: that building awareness of the brand drives more people to read our content; that by growing readership the Movement itself grows as readers are converted into content contributors; that as the community grows so does the amount and diversity of content offered; and that more, and more diverse, content attracts more readers.

entry.title: Templates and Trust-o-meters: Towards a widely deployable indicator of trust in Wikipedia
entry.summary: This work identifies three key challenges: 1) empirically determining which metrics from community approaches most impact reader trust; 2) validating indicator placements and designs; and 3) demonstrating that such indicators can both lower trust and increase perceived trust in the system when appropriate.
entry.content:
Initiative: Numeric Exploration

This work identifies three key challenges: 1) empirically determining which metrics from community approaches most impact reader trust; 2) validating indicator placements and designs; and 3) demonstrating that such indicators can both lower trust and increase perceived trust in the system when appropriate.

entry.title: Digital Spaces // Topical Neighborhoods
entry.summary: This project combined conversations with WMF employees and global volunteers with a literature review to support the internal conversation around the Digital Spaces // Topical Neighborhoods proposal.
entry.content:
Initiative: Online Social Behavior

This project combined conversations with WMF employees and global volunteers with a literature review to support the internal conversation around the Digital Spaces // Topical Neighborhoods proposal.

Lead: Michael Raish

author.name: Michael Raish

entry.title: Media Matching
entry.summary: Conducted in support of the WMF Structured Data team, Media Matching attempted to identify barriers faced by experienced editors in English, Arabic, and Japanese Wikipedias.
entry.content:
Initiative: Research & Development

Conducted in support of the WMF Structured Data team, Media Matching attempted to identify barriers faced by experienced editors in English, Arabic, and Japanese Wikipedias.

entry.title: Targets of Harassment
entry.summary: In order to support the Universal Code of Conduct’s phase 2 drafting committee, the Wikimedia Foundation has conducted a research project focused on experiences of harassment on Wikimedia projects.
entry.content:
Initiative: Online Social Behavior

In order to support the Universal Code of Conduct’s phase 2 drafting committee, the Wikimedia Foundation has conducted a research project focused on experiences of harassment on Wikimedia projects.

entry.content:

Lead: Jeff Howard

author.name: Jeff Howard

entry.title: Long Tail Topic & Influence Ontology
entry.summary: This work provides a method for visualizing and comparing topical coverage from one wiki project to another for the purpose of better understanding where knowledge gaps and subject matter expertise exist across the Free Knowledge Movement.
entry.content:
Initiative: Numeric Exploration

This work provides a method for visualizing and comparing topical coverage from one wiki project to another for the purpose of better understanding where knowledge gaps and subject matter expertise exist across the Free Knowledge Movement.

entry.summary: Qualitative research examining the perspectives on the future of education from experts, students, teachers, and parents.
entry.content:

Qualitative research examining the perspectives on the future of education from experts, students, teachers, and parents.

Lead: Ana Chang, with AfriqInsights

entry.title: Verifiability on Wikipedia
entry.summary: This three-language study provides foundational understanding for how editors work with available resources to meet the standards required for article quality.
entry.content:
Initiative: Sentiment & Perception

This three-language study provides foundational understanding for how editors work with available resources to meet the standards required for article quality.

entry.summary: A study that collects feedback on the function-builder prototype from technical users, nontechnical users, and those from outside of the Wikimedia ecosystem.
entry.content:
Initiative: Research & Development

A study that collects feedback on the function-builder prototype from technical users, nontechnical users, and those from outside of the Wikimedia ecosystem.

entry.title: Section Translation Usability Testing
entry.summary: Many Wikipedia contributors edit articles via mobile devices. Section Translation brings translation support to mobile device editors, and this project provided usability testing as the tool became available in the first wiki.
entry.content:
Initiative: Machine Augmentation

Many Wikipedia contributors edit articles via mobile devices. Section Translation brings translation support to mobile device editors, and this project provided usability testing as the tool became available in the first wiki.

entry.summary: This project tests the concept of a sticky header and the table of contents element as a part of a reader-focused desktop interface improvement initiative by the Web team.

This project tests the concept of a sticky header and the table of contents element as a part of a reader-focused desktop interface improvement initiative by the Web team.

entry.title: Decision-making & Influence
entry.summary: A collaboration to map the different types of group decision-making required to manage and improve a crowd-sourced content platform like Wikipedia and understand contributor communities as discrete social groups.
entry.content:
Initiative: Research & Development

A collaboration to map the different types of group decision-making required to manage and improve a crowd-sourced content platform like Wikipedia and understand contributor communities as discrete social groups.

entry.title: Patrolling Anonymous Edits
entry.summary: A study of how patrollers handle edits by logged-out users, and what pieces of information from IP addresses are necessary for their work in maintaining the overall health and quality of Wikimedia projects.

Initiative: Online Social Behavior

A study of how patrollers handle edits by logged-out users, and what pieces of information from IP addresses are necessary for their work in maintaining the overall health and quality of Wikimedia projects.

Lead: Claudia Lo, with the Anti-Harassment Tools team

author.name: Claudia Lo, with the Anti-Harassment Tools team

entry.title: CheckUser Improvements
entry.summary: Past research and Steward feedback surfaced many pain points in the CheckUser extension, the tool used by moderators to reverse vandalism of articles. These are multiple iterative rounds of usability tests of the enhanced tool.
entry.content:
Initiative: Online Social Behavior

Past research and Steward feedback surfaced many pain points in the CheckUser extension, the tool used by moderators to reverse vandalism of articles. These are multiple iterative rounds of usability tests of the enhanced tool.

Lead: Claudia Lo, with the Anti-Harassment Tools team

author.name: Claudia Lo, with the Anti-Harassment Tools team

entry.title: Trusted: Signals, Inferences & Indicators
entry.summary: The goal of this work is to develop systems for automatically detecting and characterizing the editorial debates behind Wikipedia articles for the purpose of surfacing indications of trustworthiness to the reader. This project is a collaboration between the Wikimedia Foundation and the CMU Human Computer Interaction Institute.
entry.content:
Initiative: Numeric Exploration

The goal of this work is to develop systems for automatically detecting and characterizing the editorial debates behind Wikipedia articles for the purpose of surfacing indications of trustworthiness to the reader. This project is a collaboration between the Wikimedia Foundation and the CMU Human Computer Interaction Institute.

Lead: Andrew Kuznetsov of the Carnegie Mellon Human Computer Interaction Institute, with Margeigh Novotny

author.name: Andrew Kuznetsov of the Carnegie Mellon Human Computer Interaction Institute, with Margeigh Novotny

entry.title: Trusted: Signals, Inferences & Indicators
entry.summary: Researchers are analyzing which types of cues work best to help readers understand the true quality of an article and scraping talk pages for the signals and inferences that can drive these cues.
entry.content:
Initiative: Research & Development

Researchers are analyzing which types of cues work best to help readers understand the true quality of an article and scraping talk pages for the signals and inferences that can drive these cues.

entry.summary: An overview of how a global community of volunteer moderators determine which contributions to Wikipedia are accepted and rejected.
entry.content:
Initiative: Powered by People

An overview of how a global community of volunteer moderators determine which contributions to Wikipedia are accepted and rejected.

entry.title: Machine Translation Meets Human Perception
entry.summary: The Machine Translation Meets Human Perception (MTMHP) study developed a protocol for evaluating how readers perceive and evaluate machine-translated content - across three different languages, cultural contexts, and content domains.
entry.content:
Initiative: Machine Augmentation

The Machine Translation Meets Human Perception (MTMHP) study developed a protocol for evaluating how readers perceive and evaluate machine-translated content - across three different languages, cultural contexts, and content domains.

entry.content:

entry.title: Free Knowledge Movement Personas

entry.content:
Initiative: Powered by People

This is a collection of all personas developed to date for desktop and mobile readers, new and veteran contributors, institutional curators and Movement organizers.

entry.title: CheckUser Workflow & Tools
entry.summary: CheckUser is a critical tool for moderators in anti-vandalism efforts on Wikipedia. This research surfaces the pain points in the CheckUser workflow and opportunities to improve the tool.
entry.content:
Initiative: Powered by People

CheckUser is a critical tool for moderators in anti-vandalism efforts on Wikipedia. This research surfaces the pain points in the CheckUser workflow and opportunities to improve the tool.

entry.title: Why Do People Edit Wikipedia?
entry.summary: This literature review examines the drivers of engagement and the motivators of sustained involvement in Wikipedia. It provides an overview of academic research on Wikipedia production and editor motivations, highlighting the themes and queries of scholarship in this area.
entry.content:
Initiative: Powered by People

This literature review examines the drivers of engagement and the motivators of sustained involvement in Wikipedia. It provides an overview of academic research on Wikipedia production and editor motivations, highlighting the themes and queries of scholarship in this area.

Lead: Anna Rader

author.name: Anna Rader

entry.title: WMF Remote Worker Experience
entry.summary: This is a lean, inward-facing research project that surfaced the challenges and highlights of working remotely for the Foundation and offered opportunities for the Foundation and non-remote staff to improve the work lives and for its globally distributed staff.
entry.content:
Initiative: Powered by People

This is a lean, inward-facing research project that surfaced the challenges and highlights of working remotely for the Foundation and offered opportunities for the Foundation and non-remote staff to improve the work lives and for its globally distributed staff.

entry.summary: This study seeks to understand the experience and sentiment of new and casual readers on Wikipedia.

This study seeks to understand the experience and sentiment of new and casual readers on Wikipedia.

entry.summary: This initiative, lead by Neil Shah-Quinn, established a baseline for comparing key characteristics of 732 wiki projects (number of editors, amount of content, readers, readers by platform, etc).
entry.content:
Initiative: Numeric Exploration

This initiative, lead by Neil Shah-Quinn, established a baseline for comparing key characteristics of 732 wiki projects (number of editors, amount of content, readers, readers by platform, etc).

author.name: Neil Shah-Quinn

entry.title: New Page Patrol
entry.summary: Content integrity on Wikipedia relies on editors who patrol articles and respond to vandalism. This research brings to light the workflows of editors who patrol on Wikipedia(s) and the tools used in the course of their work.
entry.content:
Initiative: Powered by People

Content integrity on Wikipedia relies on editors who patrol articles and respond to vandalism. This research brings to light the workflows of editors who patrol on Wikipedia(s) and the tools used in the course of their work.

author.name: Jonathan Morgan

entry.content:

Lead: Jonathan Morgan

author.name: Jonathan Morgan

entry.title: Harassment on Arabic Wikipedia
entry.summary: This study aimed to establish a baseline understanding of the frequency of harassment, trolling, and threatening communicative practices on Arabic Wikipedia, to explore the effects of these practices on editing and community health, and to guide future investigation and strategic decisions for the Anti-Harassment Tools team.
entry.content:
Initiative: Online Social Behavior

This study aimed to establish a baseline understanding of the frequency of harassment, trolling, and threatening communicative practices on Arabic Wikipedia, to explore the effects of these practices on editing and community health, and to guide future investigation and strategic decisions for the Anti-Harassment Tools team.

author.name: Mike Raish, with the Anti-Harassment Tools Team

entry.summary: A review of best practices in reporting systems for disputes and abuse across different platforms.
entry.content:
Initiative: Online Social Behavior

A review of best practices in reporting systems for disputes and abuse across different platforms.

entry.title: Steward Spambot Workflow
entry.summary: An investigation into one of the most common tasks performed by stewards, global locks of suspected spambots that are active across multiple wikis.
entry.content:

entry.title: Augmentation
entry.summary: This is a position piece developed by Wikimedia Foundation to frame the potential of machine-in-the-loop technologies in making all the world's knowledge available to all, and to ensure the process to assemble that knowledge is inclusive, balanced and safe.
entry.content:
Initiative: Machine Augmentation

This is a position piece developed by Wikimedia Foundation to frame the potential of machine-in-the-loop technologies in making all the world's knowledge available to all, and to ensure the process to assemble that knowledge is inclusive, balanced and safe.

entry.title: Contribution Workflow Taxonomy
entry.summary: This project details the workflow of contributors and assesses the level of difficulty they encounter with each step in the workflow in order to understand what contributes to editors' retention or burn-out.
entry.content:
Initiative: Powered by People

This project details the workflow of contributors and assesses the level of difficulty they encounter with each step in the workflow in order to understand what contributes to editors' retention or burn-out.

entry.summary: This study sought to understand the experiences, needs and challenges of new editors on midsize Wikipedias with the goal of learning how best to support and retain them.
entry.content:
Initiative: Powered by People

This study sought to understand the experiences, needs and challenges of new editors on midsize Wikipedias with the goal of learning how best to support and retain them.

entry.summary: This project creates a taxonomy of the contributions made by Wikimedia communities, measure the contributions in that taxonomy, and elicit trends in volunteer contributions to the projects.

Initiative: Powered by People

This project creates a taxonomy of the contributions made by Wikimedia communities, measure the contributions in that taxonomy, and elicit trends in volunteer contributions to the projects.
